awd_titl_txt: RUI: Atomically thin monolayer semiconductors for ultrasensitive UV photodetectors
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Atomically thin semiconductors for ultrasensitive UV Photodetectors

Non-technical Abstract: This research focuses on atom-thick, two-dimensional semiconductors derived from transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) with the ultimate goal to lay the foundation for developing an ultrasensitive, gigahertz speed photodetector in the ultraviolet (UV) range. Currently, such a semiconductor-based UV photodetector is not available, which hampers many high speed and low signal applications. TMD semiconductors reveal remarkable properties. Their unique crystal structure leads to the creation of a unique type of strongly bound excitons, known as van Hove singularity excitons that are created when a UV photon interacts with a TMD semiconductor. TMD materials will be studied to understand the basic physical properties of these excitons and to utilize them for optoelectronic applications in the UV region and ultimately for the development of a new ultrafast, fast-response, and high-sensitivity UV photodetector. This research is expected to have significant technological impacts ranging from everyday life to new communication tools. It will be conducted at a Primarily Undergraduate Institution and will involve undergraduate and Master's students and students from local high schools. The active participation in the project will provide students an excellent nanoscience research experience and an outstanding opportunity to train in nanoscale optoelectronics preparing them for careers in industry and academia. The principal investigator will reach out to the local community at the Annual Bay Area Science Festival to showcase the underlying principles of nanotechnology seeding public interest in science and encouraging young adults to pursue science degrees.

Technical-Abstract: Newly developed atomically thin van der Waals crystals reveal remarkable electronic, optical, and optoelectrical properties and show great promise for the development of novel nanoscale optoelectronic devices. The goal of the project is to advance the fundamental understanding of such devices by studying the intriguing properties of monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). Ultimately a prototype of a nanoscale, ultrasensitive (~few photons) and fast UV photodetector will be developed by exploiting van Hove singularity assisted excitonic transitions in atomically thin monolayer TMDs derived from MoS2, MoSe2, WS2 and WSe2. The unique crystal structures of these semiconductors create a Mexican hat-like optical band structure. The joint density of states diverges at the bottom of the Mexican hat creating the van Hove singularity. The objectives of the project are: (i) Investigate the van Hove singularity assisted optoelectronic properties of monolayer TMDs derived from bulk crystals by measuring the photocurrent spectra, photoresponsivity, and time responses. (ii) Investigate the intrinsic optoelectronic properties of large-scale chemical vapor deposited TMDs and measure their photocurrent and time responses to elucidate how line defects and grain boundaries affect the optoelectronic properties. (iii) Stack monolayer TMDs to develop a UV photodetector that exhibits high absorption, a GHz photoresponse speed, and a few photon detection ability. This research will advance the fundamental understanding of novel, many-body excitonic phenomena in physics, not only in 2D systems, but also in other nanoscale systems ranging from Bose-Einstein condensation to excitonic solar cells and has great promise for the development of scalable nanophotonic devices.

por.por_cntn:
The research project was designed to advance the fundamental understanding of nanoscale optoelectronic devices based on micro-, nano-, and optoelectronics principles and the intriguing properties of atomically thin monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). The specific objectives were to: (1) determine the intrinsic optoelectronic properties of monolayer TMDs (PC spectra, photoresponsivity and time response); (2) investigate the intrinsic opto-electronic properties of chemical vapor deposited TMDs; (3) develop a prototype of an ultrasensitive, GHz speed UV few photon detector (FPD) based on monolayer TMDs for a wide range of applications.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research has enabled discovery and innovation at the frontier of nanoelectronics and optoelectronics and has advanced the knowledge for developing ultrasensitive photodetectors in the UV range (UVPDs).

1)    Fabricated different layer MoS2 (monolayer to 5 Layers) on atomically flat Au to understand the interface properties. By using conductive AFM measurement, we demonstrated that the Schottky barrier heights depends on the layer numbers. (Fig.1).

2)    We demonstrated an ultraviolet (UV) photodetector employing the two-dimensional electron gas formed at the AlGaN/GaN interface as an interdigitated transducer.

3)    We demonstrated of a 278 V GaN avalanche photodiode offering a photoresponsivity of 60 A/W and capable of operating at high temperature with a high gain of 105.

4)  We evaluated a contact methodology between a 2D semiconductor (MoS2) and a superconductor using sputtered MoRe, which is a type II superconductor. This supercodnctor has a relatively high critical field and temperature commonly used to induce superconductivity in graphene. We demonstrated that the contact transparency is poor and that the devices do not support a measurable supercurrent down to 3 K. (Fig.2)

5)    We determined the vibration properties of Franckeite, a naturally occurring van der Waals heterostructure. By using micro-Raman spectroscopy, temperature dependent Raman spectroscopy, and density functional theory based simulation, we determined the crystal structure and all possible vibrational modes of Franckeite. (Fig.3 and Fig.4)

6)    We demonstrated that the valence band splitting in transition metal dichalcogenides depends strongly on the interlayer interactions (Fig.5).

 The research results have been widely disseminated.  This include:

  1. Paper: 7 published papers at highly respected journals, 1 manuscript under review, and 1 under preparation.  
  2. Presentations: The results have been reported in conferences and seminars tens of times.
  3. Dissertation: The results of this project consist of important parts of 4 Master?s dissertations in my group.
  4. Media coverage: The electrical properties of many layer MoS2 on ultraflat Au have received media coverage from the SFSU and was published as news article on the SFSU website.

Broader Impact: This impact of this research is profound and beyond the 2D materials. For example, the research on valence band splitting may pave the way to efficient devices based on spin-orbit coupling. Moreover, the study on the thermal properties of Franckeite may lead to nanoscale devices with efficient heat transport management. The demonstration of layer-number dependent Schottky barrier will help developing nanoscale devices with superior electronic transport properties.

The project had significant impact on the integration of education and outreach effort at San Francisco State University, a minority serving institutions. One postdoc, 6 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students and 4 high school students from my group participate this project in different ways.  In addition to, the project also involved 4 graduate students from other collaborating research groups. The research also provided research opportunities for one pre-service school teachers (under the NSF-funded STAR fellowship program) and 4 high-school students to conduct research. Overall, the training has well prepared them for career in STEM fields.
